summary: The document comprises memoranda and forms concerning the legal case USA v. Gerald P. Hemming, focusing on the role of CIA employee Thomas L. Briggs. It details the procedural steps for Briggs' approval to testify, addressing concerns over revealing his CIA affiliation and the management of his testimony. The case centers on Hemming's defense of acting under DEA orders, with the CIA implementing strategies to safeguard classified information while adhering to legal mandates.
key_findings: Thomas L. Briggs, a CIA employee, was sought to testify in Gerald P. Hemming's trial about an interview conducted during his DEA tenure.
The CIA undertook steps to conceal Briggs' identity and the sensitivity of his role, involving legal consultations and an Outside Activity Approval Request.
Briggs was prepared to serve as a rebuttal witness should Hemming assert he was directed by the DEA, illustrating the nexus between national security and judicial processes.

The document underscores the delicate equilibrium between fulfilling legal responsibilities and protecting national security, evidenced by the sealing of certain proceedings to prevent disclosure of sensitive data.
